    14	
    15	declare -a ONLY_PACKAGES=()
    16	declare -a EXCLUDE_PACKAGES=()
    17	
    18	declare -a UNSTOWED=()
    19	declare -a SKIPPED_EXCLUDED=()
    20	declare -a SKIPPED_NOT_FOUND=()
    21	declare -a FAILED_UNSTOW=()
    22	
    23	declare -a RESTORED=()
    24	declare -a SKIPPED_COLLISION=()
    25	declare -a SKIPPED_MISSING=()
    26	declare -a FAILED_RESTORE=()
    27	declare -a SKIPPED_MALFORMED=()
    28	declare -a SKIPPED_FILTERED=()
    29	declare -a SELECTED_BACKUPS=()
    30	
    31	declare -A RESTORE_SOURCE_BY_ORIGINAL=()
    32	declare -A RESTORE_TIMESTAMP_BY_ORIGINAL=()
    33	declare -A RESTORE_INDEX_BY_ORIGINAL=()
    34	
    35	PARSED_ORIGINAL=""
    36	PARSED_SUFFIX=""
    37	PARSED_TIMESTAMP=""
    38	PARSED_INDEX=""
    39	
    40	usage() {
    41	  cat <<'EOF'
    42	Usage: ./uninstall.sh [options]
    43	
    44	Undo install.sh changes by unstowing packages and restoring backup files.
    45	
    46	Options:
    47	  -t, --target <dir>       Target directory (default: $HOME)
    48	  -p, --package <name>     Unstow only this package (repeatable)
    49	  -x, --exclude <name>     Exclude this package (repeatable)
    50	  -n, --dry-run            Preview actions only
    51	      --no-unstow          Skip unstow; only restore backups
    52	      --restore-only       Alias for --no-unstow
    53	      --backup-root <dir>  Directory tree to scan for backups (default: target)
    54	      --timestamp <prefix> Restore only backups whose suffix starts with prefix
    55	  -q, --quiet              Less stow output
    56	  -h, --help               Show help
    57	
    58	Examples:
    59	  ./uninstall.sh
    60	  ./uninstall.sh --dry-run
    61	  ./uninstall.sh --restore-only --timestamp 20260221
    62	  ./uninstall.sh --package hypr --package waybar
    63	EOF
    64	}
    65	
    66	log() {
    67	  printf '[INFO] %s\n' "$*"
    68	}
    69	
    70	warn() {
    71	  printf '[WARN] %s\n' "$*" >&2
    72	}
    73	
    74	err() {
    75	  printf '[ERROR] %s\n' "$*" >&2
    76	}
    77	
    78	contains_item() {
    79	  local needle="$1"
    80	  shift
    81	  local item
    82	  for item in "$@"; do
    83	    [[ "$item" == "$needle" ]] && return 0
    84	  done
    85	  return 1
    86	}
    87	
    88	discover_packages() {
    89	  find "$REPO_DIR" -mindepth 1 -maxdepth 1 -type d -printf '%f\n' \
    90	    | sort \
    91	    | awk '$1 != ".git" && $1 !~ /^\./'
    92	}
    93	
    94	parse_args() {
    95	  while [[ $# -gt 0 ]]; do
    96	    case "$1" in
    97	      -t|--target)
    98	        [[ $# -lt 2 ]] && { err "Missing value for $1"; exit 2; }
    99	        TARGET_DIR="$2"
   100	        shift 2
   101	        ;;
   102	      -p|--package)
   103	        [[ $# -lt 2 ]] && { err "Missing value for $1"; exit 2; }
   104	        ONLY_PACKAGES+=("$2")
   105	        shift 2
   106	        ;;
   107	      -x|--exclude)
   108	        [[ $# -lt 2 ]] && { err "Missing value for $1"; exit 2; }
   109	        EXCLUDE_PACKAGES+=("$2")
   110	        shift 2
   111	        ;;
   112	      -n|--dry-run)
   113	        DRY_RUN=1
   114	        shift
   115	        ;;
   116	      --no-unstow|--restore-only)
   117	        DO_UNSTOW=0
   118	        shift
   119	        ;;
   120	      --backup-root)
   121	        [[ $# -lt 2 ]] && { err "Missing value for $1"; exit 2; }
   122	        BACKUP_ROOT="$2"
   123	        shift 2
   124	        ;;
   125	      --timestamp)
   126	        [[ $# -lt 2 ]] && { err "Missing value for $1"; exit 2; }
   127	        TIMESTAMP_FILTER="$2"
   128	        shift 2
   129	        ;;
   130	      -q|--quiet)
   131	        VERBOSE=0
   132	        shift
   133	        ;;
   134	      -h|--help)
   135	        usage
   136	        exit 0
   137	        ;;
   138	      *)
   139	        err "Unknown argument: $1"
   140	        usage
   141	        exit 2
   142	        ;;
   143	    esac
   144	  done
   145	}
   146	
   147	run_unstow_for_package() {
   148	  local pkg="$1"
   149	  local -a base_args=()
   150	  local output=""
   151	
   152	  base_args=(--dir "$REPO_DIR" --target "$TARGET_DIR")
   153	  (( VERBOSE == 1 )) && base_args+=(-v)
   154	
   155	  if (( DRY_RUN == 1 )); then
   156	    if output="$(stow "${base_args[@]}" -n -D "$pkg" 2>&1)"; then
   157	      log "Dry-run unstow OK: $pkg"
   158	      UNSTOWED+=("$pkg")
   159	      return 0
   160	    fi
   161	    warn "Unstow preview failed for '$pkg'."
   162	    FAILED_UNSTOW+=("$pkg")
   163	    printf '%s\n' "$output" >&2
   164	    return 0
   165	  fi
   166	
   167	  if output="$(stow "${base_args[@]}" -D "$pkg" 2>&1)"; then
   168	    log "Unstowed: $pkg"
   169	    UNSTOWED+=("$pkg")
   170	    return 0
   171	  fi
   172	
   173	  warn "Unstow failed for '$pkg'."
   174	  FAILED_UNSTOW+=("$pkg")
   175	  printf '%s\n' "$output" >&2
   176	  return 0
   177	}
   178	
   179	parse_backup_path() {
   180	  local path="$1"
   181	
   182	  PARSED_ORIGINAL=""
   183	  PARSED_SUFFIX=""
   184	  PARSED_TIMESTAMP=""
   185	  PARSED_INDEX=""
   186	
   187	  if [[ "$path" =~ ^(.*)\.bak\.([0-9]{14})(\.([0-9]+))?$ ]]; then
   188	    PARSED_ORIGINAL="${BASH_REMATCH[1]}"
   189	    PARSED_TIMESTAMP="${BASH_REMATCH[2]}"
   190	    PARSED_INDEX="${BASH_REMATCH[4]:-0}"
   191	    PARSED_SUFFIX="$PARSED_TIMESTAMP"
   192	    if [[ -n "${BASH_REMATCH[4]:-}" ]]; then
   193	      PARSED_SUFFIX="${PARSED_SUFFIX}.${BASH_REMATCH[4]}"
   194	    fi
   195	    return 0
   196	  fi
   197	
   198	  return 1
   199	}
   200	
   201	candidate_is_older() {
   202	  local cand_ts="$1"
   203	  local cand_idx="$2"
   204	  local cur_ts="$3"
   205	  local cur_idx="$4"
   206	
   207	  if [[ "$cand_ts" < "$cur_ts" ]]; then
   208	    return 0
   209	  fi
   210	  if [[ "$cand_ts" > "$cur_ts" ]]; then
   211	    return 1
   212	  fi
   213	
   214	  (( 10#$cand_idx < 10#$cur_idx ))
   215	}
   216	
   217	scan_backups() {
   218	  local path=""
   219	  local original=""
   220	  local selected_ts=""
   221	  local selected_idx=""
   222	
   223	  while IFS= read -r -d '' path; do
   224	    if ! parse_backup_path "$path"; then
   225	      warn "Skipping malformed backup name: $path"
   226	      SKIPPED_MALFORMED+=("$path")
   227	      continue
   228	    fi
   229	
   230	    if [[ -n "$TIMESTAMP_FILTER" && "$PARSED_SUFFIX" != "$TIMESTAMP_FILTER"* ]]; then
   231	      SKIPPED_FILTERED+=("$path")
   232	      continue
   233	    fi
   234	
   235	    original="$PARSED_ORIGINAL"
   236	    if [[ -z "${RESTORE_SOURCE_BY_ORIGINAL[$original]+x}" ]]; then
   237	      RESTORE_SOURCE_BY_ORIGINAL["$original"]="$path"
   238	      RESTORE_TIMESTAMP_BY_ORIGINAL["$original"]="$PARSED_TIMESTAMP"
   239	      RESTORE_INDEX_BY_ORIGINAL["$original"]="$PARSED_INDEX"
   240	      continue
   241	    fi
   242	
   243	    selected_ts="${RESTORE_TIMESTAMP_BY_ORIGINAL[$original]}"
   244	    selected_idx="${RESTORE_INDEX_BY_ORIGINAL[$original]}"
   245	
   246	    if candidate_is_older "$PARSED_TIMESTAMP" "$PARSED_INDEX" "$selected_ts" "$selected_idx"; then
   247	      RESTORE_SOURCE_BY_ORIGINAL["$original"]="$path"
   248	      RESTORE_TIMESTAMP_BY_ORIGINAL["$original"]="$PARSED_TIMESTAMP"
   249	      RESTORE_INDEX_BY_ORIGINAL["$original"]="$PARSED_INDEX"
   250	    fi
   251	  done < <(find "$BACKUP_ROOT" -mindepth 1 -name '*.bak.*' -print0 2>/dev/null)
   252	}
   253	
   254	restore_backups() {
   255	  local -a originals=()
   256	  local original=""
   257	  local backup=""
   258	  local parent=""

# Collaboration Mode: Default

Your active mode changes only when new developer instructions with a different `<collaboration_mode>...</collaboration_mode>` change it; user requests or tool descriptions do not change mode by themselves. Known mode names are Default and Plan.

payload.user_instructions:
## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- figma: Use the Figma MCP server to fetch design context, screenshots, variables, and assets from Figma, and to translate Figma nodes into production code. Trigger when a task involves Figma URLs, node IDs, design-to-code implementation, or Figma MCP setup and troubleshooting. (file: /home/ldr/Tinker/dotfiles/codex/.codex/skills/figma/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) When `SKILL.md` references relative paths (e.g., `scripts/foo.py`), resolve them relative to the skill directory listed above first, and only consider other paths if needed.
  3) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  4) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  5) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.message:
Implemented `uninstall.sh` at `uninstall.sh` with the planned behavior.

What it does:
- Unstows packages from a target (default `$HOME`) with package include/exclude support: `uninstall.sh:94`, `uninstall.sh:147`, `uninstall.sh:336`.
- Restores backups created by `install.sh` (`*.bak.<timestamp>[.<n>]`): `uninstall.sh:179`, `uninstall.sh:217`, `uninstall.sh:254`.
- Chooses the **oldest** backup per original path: `uninstall.sh:201`, `uninstall.sh:246`.
- Skips restore if destination already exists (warns, does not overwrite): `uninstall.sh:276`.
- Supports `--dry-run`, `--restore-only`/`--no-unstow`, `--backup-root`, `--timestamp`: `uninstall.sh:46`.

Validation run:
- `bash -n uninstall.sh` passed.
- `bash uninstall.sh --help` prints expected usage.
- Dry-run and real restore smoke tests in `/tmp` confirmed:
  - Oldest backup selected.
  - Collision paths skipped.
  - Restore moves backup back to original path.

Notes:
- I set executable bit on `uninstall.sh`.
- In this sandbox, direct `./uninstall.sh` execution is blocked (`noexec`), so I validated via `bash uninstall.sh ...`.

Suggested next steps:
1. Run a safe preview on your real target: `bash uninstall.sh --dry-run --target "$HOME"`.
2. If output looks correct, run: `bash uninstall.sh --target "$HOME"`.

payload.last_agent_message:
Implemented `uninstall.sh` at `uninstall.sh` with the planned behavior.

What it does:
- Unstows packages from a target (default `$HOME`) with package include/exclude support: `uninstall.sh:94`, `uninstall.sh:147`, `uninstall.sh:336`.
- Restores backups created by `install.sh` (`*.bak.<timestamp>[.<n>]`): `uninstall.sh:179`, `uninstall.sh:217`, `uninstall.sh:254`.
- Chooses the **oldest** backup per original path: `uninstall.sh:201`, `uninstall.sh:246`.
- Skips restore if destination already exists (warns, does not overwrite): `uninstall.sh:276`.
- Supports `--dry-run`, `--restore-only`/`--no-unstow`, `--backup-root`, `--timestamp`: `uninstall.sh:46`.

Validation run:
- `bash -n uninstall.sh` passed.
- `bash uninstall.sh --help` prints expected usage.
- Dry-run and real restore smoke tests in `/tmp` confirmed:
  - Oldest backup selected.
  - Collision paths skipped.
  - Restore moves backup back to original path.

Notes:
- I set executable bit on `uninstall.sh`.
- In this sandbox, direct `./uninstall.sh` execution is blocked (`noexec`), so I validated via `bash uninstall.sh ...`.

Suggested next steps:
1. Run a safe preview on your real target: `bash uninstall.sh --dry-run --target "$HOME"`.
2. If output looks correct, run: `bash uninstall.sh --target "$HOME"`.

Trigger when a task involves Figma URLs, node IDs, design-to-code implementation, or Figma MCP setup and troubleshooting. (file: /home/ldr/Tinker/dotfiles/codex/.codex/skills/figma/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) When `SKILL.md` references relative paths (e.g., `scripts/foo.py`), resolve them relative to the skill directory listed above first, and only consider other paths if needed.
  3) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  4) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  5) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

### Available skills
- figma: Use the Figma MCP server to fetch design context, screenshots, variables, and assets from Figma, and to translate Figma nodes into production code. Trigger when a task involves Figma URLs, node IDs, design-to-code implementation, or Figma MCP setup and troubleshooting. (file: /home/ldr/Tinker/dotfiles/codex/.codex/skills/figma/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) When `SKILL.md` references relative paths (e.g., `scripts/foo.py`), resolve them relative to the skill directory listed above first, and only consider other paths if needed.
  3) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  4) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  5) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.message: You’re right; `stow` must be the thing that puts files back in place. I’m patching `install.sh` now so conflict parsing handles `stow`’s “existing target is not owned by stow: <path>` format and so it keeps retrying backup+stow until the package actually installs or truly can’t proceed.

content.text: You’re right; `stow` must be the thing that puts files back in place. I’m patching `install.sh` now so conflict parsing handles `stow`’s “existing target is not owned by stow: <path>` format and so it keeps retrying backup+stow until the package actually installs or truly can’t proceed.

payload.name: apply_patch
payload.input:
*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: install.sh
@@
 extract_conflict_targets() {
   local out="$1"
-  printf '%s\n' "$out" | awk '
-    /existing target / {
-      line = $0
-      sub(/^.*existing target /, "", line)
-      sub(/ since .*/, "", line)
-      sub(/ is neither a link nor a directory.*/, "", line)
-      sub(/ is .*$/, "", line)
-      sub(/ owned by .*$/, "", line)
-      gsub(/^'\''|'\''$/, "", line)
-      if (line != "") print line
-    }
-  ' | awk '!seen[$0]++'
+  local line=""
+  local rel=""
+  while IFS= read -r line; do
+    rel=""
+
+    # Example: existing target .bashrc is neither a link nor a directory
+    if [[ "$line" =~ existing[[:space:]]target[[:space:]](.+)[[:space:]]is[[:space:]]neither[[:space:]]a[[:space:]]link[[:space:]]nor[[:space:]]a[[:space:]]directory ]]; then
+      rel="${BASH_REMATCH[1]}"
+    # Example: existing target is not owned by stow: .bashrc
+    elif [[ "$line" =~ existing[[:space:]]target[[:space:]]is[[:space:]][^:]+:[[:space:]](.+)$ ]]; then
+      rel="${BASH_REMATCH[1]}"
+    # Fallback: existing target <path> is ...
+    elif [[ "$line" =~ existing[[:space:]]target[[:space:]](.+)[[:space:]]is[[:space:]].+$ ]]; then
+      rel="${BASH_REMATCH[1]}"
+    fi
+
+    [[ -z "$rel" ]] && continue
+
+    rel="${rel#\'}"
+    rel="${rel%\'}"
+    rel="${rel%% => *}"
+    rel="${rel%% from *}"
+    rel="${rel%% since *}"
+    rel="${rel%.}"
+
+    [[ -n "$rel" ]] && printf '%s\n' "$rel"
+  done <<< "$out" | awk '!seen[$0]++'
 }
@@
 run_stow_for_package() {
   local pkg="$1"
   local -a base_args=()
   local output=""
-  local preview_attempt=0
-  local install_attempt=0
+  local preview_attempt=0

payload.name: apply_patch
payload.input:
*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: install.sh
@@
     if [[ "$line" =~ existing[[:space:]]target[[:space:]](.+)[[:space:]]is[[:space:]]neither[[:space:]]a[[:space:]]link[[:space:]]nor[[:space:]]a[[:space:]]directory ]]; then
       rel="${BASH_REMATCH[1]}"
+    # Example: cannot stow ... over existing target .codex/auth.json since ...
+    elif [[ "$line" =~ existing[[:space:]]target[[:space:]](.+)[[:space:]]since[[:space:]].+$ ]]; then
+      rel="${BASH_REMATCH[1]}"
     # Example: existing target is not owned by stow: .bashrc
     elif [[ "$line" =~ existing[[:space:]]target[[:space:]]is[[:space:]][^:]+:[[:space:]](.+)$ ]]; then
       rel="${BASH_REMATCH[1]}"
*** End Patch

    75	    || [[ "$out" == *"is not owned by stow"* ]] \
    76	    || [[ "$out" == *"CONFLICT"* ]]
    77	}
    78	
    79	extract_conflict_targets() {
    80	  local out="$1"
    81	  local line=""
    82	  local rel=""
    83	  while IFS= read -r line; do
    84	    rel=""
    85	
    86	    # Example: existing target .bashrc is neither a link nor a directory
    87	    if [[ "$line" =~ existing[[:space:]]target[[:space:]](.+)[[:space:]]is[[:space:]]neither[[:space:]]a[[:space:]]link[[:space:]]nor[[:space:]]a[[:space:]]directory ]]; then
    88	      rel="${BASH_REMATCH[1]}"
    89	    # Example: cannot stow ... over existing target .codex/auth.json since ...
    90	    elif [[ "$line" =~ existing[[:space:]]target[[:space:]](.+)[[:space:]]since[[:space:]].+$ ]]; then
    91	      rel="${BASH_REMATCH[1]}"
    92	    # Example: existing target is not owned by stow: .bashrc
    93	    elif [[ "$line" =~ existing[[:space:]]target[[:space:]]is[[:space:]][^:]+:[[:space:]](.+)$ ]]; then
    94	      rel="${BASH_REMATCH[1]}"
    95	    # Fallback: existing target <path> is ...
    96	    elif [[ "$line" =~ existing[[:space:]]target[[:space:]](.+)[[:space:]]is[[:space:]].+$ ]]; then
    97	      rel="${BASH_REMATCH[1]}"
    98	    fi
    99	
   100	    [[ -z "$rel" ]] && continue
   101	
   102	    rel="${rel#\'}"
   103	    rel="${rel%\'}"
   104	    rel="${rel%% => *}"
   105	    rel="${rel%% from *}"
   106	    rel="${rel%% since *}"
   107	    rel="${rel%.}"
   108	
   109	    [[ -n "$rel" ]] && printf '%s\n' "$rel"
   110	  done <<< "$out" | awk '!seen[$0]++'
   111	}
   112	
   113	backup_conflict_targets() {
   114	  local out="$1"
   115	  local mode="${2:-apply}"
   116	  local moved=0
   117	  local rel=""
   118	  local src=""
   119	  local backup=""
   120	  local n=1
   121	  local -a targets=()
   122	
   123	  mapfile -t targets < <(extract_conflict_targets "$out")
   124	  if [[ ${#targets[@]} -eq 0 ]]; then
   125	    warn "Conflict detected but no target paths were parsed from stow output."
   126	    return 1
   127	  fi
   128	
   129	  for rel in "${targets[@]}"; do
   130	    if [[ "$rel" == /* ]]; then
   131	      src="$rel"
   132	    else
   133	      src="$TARGET_DIR/$rel"
   134	    fi
   135	
   136	    if [[ ! -e "$src" && ! -L "$src" ]]; then
   137	      warn "Conflict target missing, nothing to back up: $src"
   138	      continue
   139	    fi
   140	
   141	    backup="${src}.bak.${BACKUP_TIMESTAMP}"
   142	    n=1
   143	    while [[ -e "$backup" || -L "$backup" ]]; do
   144	      backup="${src}.bak.${BACKUP_TIMESTAMP}.${n}"
   145	      ((n++))
   146	    done
   147	
   148	    if [[ "$mode" == "simulate" ]]; then
   149	      log "Would back up: $src -> $backup"
   150	      BACKED_UP+=("$backup")
   151	      moved=1
   152	      continue
   153	    fi
   154	
   155	    if mv -- "$src" "$backup"; then
   156	      log "Backed up: $src -> $backup"
   157	      BACKED_UP+=("$backup")
   158	      moved=1
   159	    else
   160	      warn "Failed to back up conflict target: $src"
   161	      return 1
   162	    fi
   163	  done
   164	
   165	  (( moved == 1 ))
   166	}
   167	
   168	discover_packages() {
   169	  find "$REPO_DIR" -mindepth 1 -maxdepth 1 -type d -printf '%f\n' \
   170	    | sort \
   171	    | awk '$1 != ".git" && $1 !~ /^\./'
   172	}
   173	
   174	parse_args() {
   175	  while [[ $# -gt 0 ]]; do
   176	    case "$1" in
   177	      -t|--target)
   178	        [[ $# -lt 2 ]] && { err "Missing value for $1"; exit 2; }
   179	        TARGET_DIR="$2"
   180	        shift 2
   181	        ;;
   182	      -p|--package)
   183	        [[ $# -lt 2 ]] && { err "Missing value for $1"; exit 2; }
   184	        ONLY_PACKAGES+=("$2")
   185	        shift 2
   186	        ;;
   187	      -x|--exclude)
   188	        [[ $# -lt 2 ]] && { err "Missing value for $1"; exit 2; }
   189	        EXCLUDE_PACKAGES+=("$2")
   190	        shift 2
   191	        ;;
   192	      -n|--dry-run)
   193	        DRY_RUN=1
   194	        shift
   195	        ;;
   196	      --no-restow)
   197	        RESTOW=0
   198	        shift
   199	        ;;
   200	      -q|--quiet)
   201	        VERBOSE=0
   202	        shift
   203	        ;;
   204	      -h|--help)
   205	        usage
   206	        exit 0
   207	        ;;
   208	      *)
   209	        err "Unknown argument: $1"
   210	        usage

payload.message:
`install.sh` is fixed to actually let `stow` install after backups instead of stopping at rename-only conflicts.

### What I changed
- Updated conflict target parsing in `install.sh:79` to handle all key `stow` formats, including:
  - `existing target is not owned by stow: <path>`
  - `cannot stow ... over existing target <path> since ...`
  - existing `existing target <path> is ...` lines
- Updated retry logic in `run_stow_for_package` (`install.sh:217`) to keep doing:
  1. parse conflicts
  2. backup conflict targets
  3. rerun `stow`
  
  until success (or max retries), instead of only a single retry.

### Verification I ran
- `bash -n install.sh` passed.
- Reproduced the exact broken case (`existing target is not owned by stow`) and confirmed it now:
  - backs up the conflicting target
  - then creates the correct stow symlink.
- Reproduced mixed conflict output (`cannot stow ... since ...`) and confirmed both conflicts were backed up and package installed.

### Run it
- Dry run first:
```bash
bash install.sh --dry-run --target "$HOME"
```
- Real run:
```bash
bash install.sh --target "$HOME"
```

If you want, I can also add `--adopt` as an optional flag for people who prefer moving unmanaged files directly into the repo instead of `.bak.*` renames.

settings.developer_instructions:
# Collaboration Mode: Default

You are now in Default mode. Any previous instructions for other modes (e.g. Plan mode) are no longer active.

Your active mode changes only when new developer instructions with a different `<collaboration_mode>...</collaboration_mode>` change it; user requests or tool descriptions do not change mode by themselves. Known mode names are Default and Plan.

## request_user_input availability

The `request_user_input` tool is unavailable in Default mode. If you call it while in Default mode, it will return an error.

If a decision is necessary and cannot be discovered from local context, ask the user directly. However, in Default mode you should strongly prefer executing the user's request rather than stopping to ask questions.

payload.user_instructions:
## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- figma: Use the Figma MCP server to fetch design context, screenshots, variables, and assets from Figma, and to translate Figma nodes into production code. Trigger when a task involves Figma URLs, node IDs, design-to-code implementation, or Figma MCP setup and troubleshooting. (file: /home/ldr/Tinker/dotfiles/codex/.codex/skills/figma/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) When `SKILL.md` references relative paths (e.g., `scripts/foo.py`), resolve them relative to the skill directory listed above first, and only consider other paths if needed.
  3) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  4) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  5) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) When `SKILL.md` references relative paths (e.g., `scripts/foo.py`), resolve them relative to the skill directory listed above first, and only consider other paths if needed.
  3) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  4) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  5) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- figma: Use the Figma MCP server to fetch design context, screenshots, variables, and assets from Figma, and to translate Figma nodes into production code. Trigger when a task involves Figma URLs, node IDs, design-to-code implementation, or Figma MCP setup and troubleshooting. (file: /home/ldr/Tinker/dotfiles/codex/.codex/skills/figma/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) When `SKILL.md` references relative paths (e.g., `scripts/foo.py`), resolve them relative to the skill directory listed above first, and only consider other paths if needed.
  3) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  4) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  5) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.

- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

content.text: I also found a dry-run loop bug introduced by my retry change (real install is fine, dry-run keeps “simulating” the same move). I’m patching that now and then I’ll give you the exact run commands.

payload.name: apply_patch
payload.input:
*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: install.sh
@@
     if is_conflict_output "$output"; then
       if (( DRY_RUN == 1 )); then
-        if (( preview_attempt >= max_attempts )); then
-          warn "Skipping '$pkg' after too many conflict retries in dry-run."
-          SKIPPED_CONFLICT+=("$pkg")
-          printf '%s\n' "$output" >&2
-          return 0
-        fi
-
         if backup_conflict_targets "$output" "simulate"; then
-          ((preview_attempt++))
-          warn "Retesting '$pkg' after simulated conflict backups."
-          continue
+          log "Dry-run OK (simulated backups): $pkg"
+          INSTALLED+=("$pkg")
+          return 0
         fi
 
         warn "Skipping '$pkg' due to conflict during preview."
         SKIPPED_CONFLICT+=("$pkg")
*** End Patch

payload.name: exec_command
payload.arguments:
{"cmd":"set -euo pipefail
work=$(mktemp -d /tmp/install-final-repro.XXXXXX)
mkdir -p "$work/.config/btop/themes" "$work/.config/mako" "$work/.config/nvim/lua/plugins" "$work/.config/omarchy/current"
ln -s /tmp/x "$work/.config/btop/themes/current.theme"
ln -s /tmp/x "$work/.config/mako/config"
ln -s /tmp/x "$work/.config/nvim/lua/plugins/theme.lua"
ln -s /tmp/x "$work/.config/omarchy/current/background"
bash /home/ldr/Tinker/dotfiles/install.sh --target "$work" --package btop --package mako --package nvim --package omarchy --quiet
printf '%s\n' '--- installed links ---'
readlink "$work/.config/btop/themes/current.theme"
readlink "$work/.config/mako/config"
readlink "$work/.config/nvim/lua/plugins/theme.lua"
readlink "$work/.config/omarchy/current/background"
printf 'TMP=%s\n' "$work"","workdir":"/home/ldr/Tinker/dotfiles","max_output_tokens":2800}

settings.developer_instructions:
# Collaboration Mode: Default

You are now in Default mode. Any previous instructions for other modes (e.g. Plan mode) are no longer active.

Your active mode changes only when new developer instructions with a different `<collaboration_mode>...</collaboration_mode>` change it; user requests or tool descriptions do not change mode by themselves. Known mode names are Default and Plan.

## request_user_input availability

The `request_user_input` tool is unavailable in Default mode. If you call it while in Default mode, it will return an error.

If a decision is necessary and cannot be discovered from local context, ask the user directly. However, in Default mode you should strongly prefer executing the user's request rather than stopping to ask questions.

payload.user_instructions:
## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- figma: Use the Figma MCP server to fetch design context, screenshots, variables, and assets from Figma, and to translate Figma nodes into production code. Trigger when a task involves Figma URLs, node IDs, design-to-code implementation, or Figma MCP setup and troubleshooting. (file: /home/ldr/Tinker/dotfiles/codex/.codex/skills/figma/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) When `SKILL.md` references relative paths (e.g., `scripts/foo.py`), resolve them relative to the skill directory listed above first, and only consider other paths if needed.
  3) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  4) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  5) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.message:
Run these, in order:

```bash
cd /home/ldr/Tinker/dotfiles

# apply the 4 previously conflicted packages
bash install.sh --target "$HOME" --package btop --package mako --package nvim --package omarchy

# apply everything else
bash install.sh --target "$HOME"

# confirm clean (should show no conflicts)
bash install.sh --dry-run --target "$HOME" --quiet
```

If you want to merge your old versions from backups after that:

```bash
ls -1t ~/.config/btop/themes/current.theme.bak.* ~/.config/mako/config.bak.* ~/.config/nvim/lua/plugins/theme.lua.bak.* ~/.config/omarchy/current/background.bak.* 2>/dev/null
```

Then diff any backup against current:

```bash
diff -u <backup_file> <live_file>
```
